She, who has never been in a place like that, was in pure awe. The starts right after she discovers this magnificent world.In my opinion the story was good. Also the story was very exciting at a lot of points during the story. I think that the book and the movie were quite similar. In the movie the dialogue seemed more up to date and it showed more things that would make you understand. The movie, on the downside left out some minor situations that the book did not. I'm not a big reader so I thought the movie better suited me, but if you're a big reader the book would be a better choice. There is more in the book apposed to the movie, also in the book things are better explained. I thought altogether that the Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe was an all around good book and movie.

title: Beautiful, warm, lovely movie bringing back the child in you
content: Based on reviews I read in advance, didn't expect much from this movie at all. In fact, I was expecting to sleep through part of the movie. But boy, was I wrong! There are these kind of movies, where after the first few shots you know you are going to love the rest of it. This was precisely the case. The parting of children from their mother in London was shot just beautiful, full of rich emotion, yet steering clear of being pathetic.This remains the case for the rest of the film. Were it set into different background, I would probably sneeze at it, calling it pathetic and emotionally overcharged. But in conjunction with the beautiful tender story of small children living out their fantasies, it just all seems to work.Performances by the child actors are very satisfactory with some and exceptional with others. While I didn't like both of the boy's acting as much, I found the young girls brilliant. Lucy in particular, being the youngest child, is basically driving the whole atmosphere of the movie and should have been maybe given even bigger space.Overall, the movie left a very warm and cosy feeling in me, it made me sit at the edge of the seat and feel like a small child again. Very, very recommended.

title: Made me feel like a child again
content: Growing up, my favorite films tended to involve ordinary people thrust into unordinary situations. Part of the fun was the hope that someday, somehow I would become one of those people and explore places that were deemed impossible to exist. As I got older and became an adult, I accepted the harsh realities of the real world and that I would never end up like the heroes that I cheered on screen. The innocence and the warm feelings of my youth became extinct.The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe brought those feelings back, if just for the two and a half hours of the film's running time. This is the best fantasy film released since 1984's The Neverending Story. Any relation to the real world and the logic we have all become accustomed to should be discarded upon viewing, because that's not what the film is about. The audience is in the shoes of the four main heroes of the film as they explore and discover all the wonders of this new world and its strange mysteries for themselves.The story is often hailed as a representation of the Christian belief and is well-acclaimed by its followers. However, there is no reason for Atheists to discard this film, by any means. It is not a retelling or adaptation of the story of the life of Jesus Christ. It merely makes references and borrows ideas from the bible to help develop their own characters. And it all works. By the time the film ends, the audience will care deeply for the heroes and cheer for them all the way through the many exciting turns and situations they encounter.Terrific film. Highly recommended.

title: unconvincing and badly acted
content: Loved the books, I have to say. But this film, right from the beginning, fails to convince. It's impossible to be carried along with it; everything is too unlikely and the child actors are, unfortunately, terrible. The director lets them down horribly - it should at least be possible to relate to their characters, but they are allowed to behave in the most preposterous ways. Only the most credulous would be able to settle down and watch this film. The rest of us, after 5 minutes, are wishing we're somewhere else.That just about says all you need to know.The rest of this review is padding to make up the requisite ten lines - I suggest you read no further.There is no god. Christian allegories are best forgotten as an embarrassing part of the human race's history.

title: Absolutely fantastic - In my opinion, better than the books...
content: I have seen this film more times than I can count, and haven't once gotten bored of it! What impresses me every time is the perfection of the child cast - they are fantastic young actors and actresses, and I particularly enjoy Skandar Keynes' performance as Edmund. In fact, pretty much everything in this production is close to perfection - the sets, the costumes, the script - everything comes together to make a beautiful film. The continued brilliance of this film is that it is perfect for all the family - you will never be too old to enter the magic of Narnia... I did read the books as a child, and although they were fantastic, I feel that I just 'clicked' more with the film adaption of this timeless tale, perhaps because of the more 'epic' feel to it when C S Lewis' beautiful story is up on the big screen. I do also feel that the film narrative is quite close to the book - always a positive thing!Don't miss this incredible film - it will be a very valuable asset to your film collection!

title: Wonderful switch
content: When my family, who almost all have grown up on The Chronicles of Narnia series, heard that Disney was coming out with the movies we were all hesitant to see them because we knew that Disney had this thing about making up a whole new story line. We were happy to see that Narnia was extremely close to the book and that they did not stray too far. I believe that this is a movie worth seeing. Also I can not wait for the next movie come to come out because I believe that the children who portray the Pevensies were absolutely amazing. All in all I believe that The Chronicles of Narnia made a great switch from book to movie. :-D

title: Rainy Nights and Turkish Delight
content: This movie is best watched during a rainy night with a cup of hot chocolate (and maybe some turkish delight). From the score to the soothing sound of Aslan's voice, this film is calming and peaceful. The acting is surprisingly good, the character development is at the forefront (especially for Edmund) and the setting is gorgeous. There is a lot to love about this movie.With a great message of redemption and sacrifice at its core, The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe is a film that I watch when I want to feel something.Note: First act Edmund is the worst!2nd Note: The White Witch is still absolutely terrifying.

title: Take me back to the Shire
content:
The good -
Love the score - Scenes between James Mcavoy and the little girl feel genuine the beavers were funny - the witch's acting and the first 20/30mins does set up a potentially magical fantasy film but soon begins to nose dive.Bad -
Overall acting - shallow character building and plot considering the length of film - Poor cgi scenes -
Ritual pagan-esque scene was inappropriate for PGThe 10/10 reviews baffle me; I won't be bothering with the sequels which is a shame because the series could have been great

title: It was so real, the images came to life !
content: During the movie, I was so taken by the fact, this movie was so real. It was as if, this movie read my mind when it came to the images from the book I had created in my mind. It was really freaky! It was as if I had met and knew the kids. The story which I have not read these books in over 25 years. I found this movie to be a grand way to bring the words of great books to life. My sister and I love this movie, but we wished it had been longer. It went by so fast, maybe cause we were so over taken by it. But it did seem to have covered so much so fast. Also I was even taken with by the idea of the Biblical view of this movie. It was a great movie Good vs. Evil. I just flat out LOVED IT !!!!

title: The infamous story is well-known
content: Excellent unremarkable costumes, special effects, and the story-line itself. A classic. I am so disappointed to see it fall behind Harry Potter. Not that Harry Potter isn't a great series as well but this movie was breathtaking. The acting and history of these stories should make this movie #1 for 2005. It is in so many Narnia fans opinions. I was so pleased and interested to see these characters come to life, I hope that the story will continue in the movie's but with these ratings it looks as though the public was not pleased? May I ask why? This is an excellent piece, highly-recommended!This story of Lucy the girl and her siblings (one older sister ) and her brother Peter escape reality into the mysterious wardrobe to find another world. Perfectly magic contents reveal another land-Narnia. The Chronicles of Narnia correlate so well with the most well written delightful books. The child Lucy, ventures off into the land to discover evils as well as friends. She comes back into the human world to discover that Narnia stops the time clock.She recruits her siblings...and you need to see for the exciting rest of mythology come to life.

title: « Welcome to Duloch, such a perfect place »
content: « Welcome to Duloch, such a perfect place » : sugarcoated, soulless, lifeless, artificial, phony, kitsch and without imagination. Interesting irony: the director of "Shrek" doing this. I guess he felt he needed to apologize from too much subversive thinking.The huge success of this so-called « movie » tells a lot about our society and the way people want to « dream » nowadays. It's frightening. It's been a long time since I have attended something so lifeless, watered-down, sugary, tame, devoid of any genuine emotion, entirely virtual and fabricated. In comparison, the blockbusters that it tries to emulate (the LOTR and Harry Potter movies) look like timeless masterpieces, and this is coming from someone who'd rather eat a cactus than attend a LOTR movie ever again, as bombast and overkill tend to make me feel nauseous. As for the HP movies, I only celebrated the third one as a « real » movie, thanks to the extremely talented Alfonso Cuaron. To each his own, for my part I'm still in love with Scott's « Legend » (the export version, with Goldsmith's score, not the awful USA cut / Tangerine dream one) as nothing has ever come close to it in terms of painting a fantasy/magical world on the screen. Yes, it's mushy, but it works. Scott was a genius, at this time, at pulling off coherent, alive, breathing, working cinematic worlds (Alien, Blade Runner, Legend).Here, everything you look at is artless and lifeless, just petty/pretty, sugarcoated pinch-beck images, a « 3-D Barbie fantasy show » as a friend of mine called this, CGI prowess presented as great achievements while being just pseudo-realistic digital dolls on a stage (it kinda looks like the real thing until you try to smell it and discover it has no smell whatsoever, or any taste for that matter) while all sense of depth, substance, emotion, soul, magic, is meticulously wiped off. The whole thing looks like a phony plastic Xmas tree. Pretty to look at, but anyone used to a real tree can only be very disappointed, and feel sad that the magic is gone.As usual, Tilda is absolutely jaw-dropping. A Queen she is indeed, not only in the story but in the movie team as well. Looks like she was the only artistically competent (grown-up) person in this team. Why such a fantastic actress isn't hired for A-works (artistically speaking) is beyond me.If you like real fantasy, look somewhere else. If you insist on having some family sugar-coated evening, even the Sound of Music and Mary Poppins are leagues ahead this soulless digital fest. Watch these again instead. Want the real thing ? (Re) discover Legend, the fully restored director's cut.

title: Best Fantasy Film I ever watched !
content:
The Chronicles of Narnia is definitely excellent film I watched.This is the best Fantasy Film ever existed with amazing Script & Editors 👏🏻
It was a Pleasure to watch this film 😍
ALL THE STAR CASTS 🌟 WILL BE FOREVER RULING IN OUR HEARTS.Narnia 2 & 3 also tried their best but was not better than Narnia 1 which is just outstanding 😉

title: A Good Yarn
content: Although not in the same league with the already legendary Lord of the Rings pictures, director Andrew Adamson (of Shrek heritage) has brought C.S. Lewis' "The Chronicles of Narnia" to the silver-screen with unusual humanity and style. In a courageous attempt to capitalize on recent trends of audience infatuation with the fantasy genre Walden Media and Walt Disney Pictures brought us an expensive yet delightful holiday treat in the form of "The Lion with Witch and the Wardrobe".A great many things about Adamson's adaptation of the Lewis books are very impressive. Interestingly though I did not feel startled by the quality of special effects. Perhaps LOTR/ WETA have ruined my view of effects for several years to come. But despite lacking a great many new thrills in the technology department Adamson has other tricks up his sleeve. I was especially impressed with the performances of the film's most integral parts, the Pevensie children. Despite risks of being overwhelmed by the abundance of CG characters, landscapes, and the resulting scenes, the four young actors who took on the lead roles of Lewis' valiant children proved themselves by excelling in almost every category. Skandar Keynes did well in producing the necessary audience feelings of disdain and eventual embrace of his surly but lovable Edmund. Anna Popplewell seemed like an old hand compared to her co-stars and handled her screen-time with grace and poise that is enviable for many of today's stars. William Moseley did justice to the character but he failed to make a resounding statement with his performance (I would be surprised if he is successful in turning his Narnia time into a long-term career). However, the most remarkable scenes in Narnia are not produced by the grandeur of special effects but instead by a tiny little girl named Georgie Henley. In the history of the cinema directors have shown sick fascination with hinging their films on the performances of children. While most people remember the positive moments in the history of film and children e.g. "Sixth Sense", "E.T.", "Oliver!" there have been a hundred times as many distinct failures (Brandon De Wilde's "Shane" is my personal favorite). And in other cases failure has not been outright and is instead replaced by mediocrity of child performers which has led to mediocrity of the film as well e.g. "The Road to Perdition". Although her performance is not what the film hinges upon for its overall effect it might as well have because 10 year-old Georgie Henley provides the deepest magic you find in Narnia. Henley completely pulled me into the story every instant in which she was the focus of a scene. Her on-screen communication does not even walk a fine line with overacting, it remains perfectly within the boundaries of subtlety and magnificently communicates the innocence and fiery spirit of her character. My favorite scenes of the film are played out between Henley's Lucy and James McAvoy's good-hearted faun Mr. Tumnus (McAvoy is particularly outstanding among the supporting players).Tilda Swinton's turn as the white witch was a primary reason for my interest in the film. However, I was relatively unimpressed with how her performance played out. Certainly Swinton did an admirable job but she lacked anything extra that truly made her stand out amidst the quagmire of CG characters. This role could have kept Swinton in mainstream villainous or powerful female parts for life but I am afraid she did not do enough with her screen time to justify any special attention. She will likely never become a contemporary of Cate Blanchett as she, and her promoters, may want her to be. Jim Broadbent's precious few moments of screen-time are everything any Broadbent fan would want them to be. He handles himself as always with unequivocal dignity and produces a fantastic sense of mystery as the ancient and secretive professor.The quality of voice acting is certainly good. Ray Winstone, Rupert Everett, Dawn French and many other talented individuals lent their professionalism to the project and they add to Narnia's mystical ambiance marvelously. Liam Neeson took on the difficult role of Aslan (Narnia's equivalent of the Messiah) and I am sad to report that he simply does not have the ability to voice a lion like James Earl Jones (Mufassa from Lion King). Neeson has proved himself time and again to be one of the great modern-day thespians but he just lacks the power Aslan needed (and could only be provided in my view by Jones).As a whole Narnia presents itself as a very good children's fantasy epic. However, Lewis' high focus on child content will leave Narnia out of any serious consideration for awards and status in the history of movie-making. Peter Jackson's Lord of the Ring's will stand a test of time that Narnia cannot and will not. Still, Andrew Adamson's direction shows that he has the stuff to be a lasting directorial force in Hollywood (and with the success of the Shrek film's why not?). Not only does Adamson strut his technical stuff he also displays an uncanny understanding of what makes a movie humanistic and fantastic without exploiting or stretching an audience's collective imagination. He and his screen-writers cleverly expanded on Lewis' storyline (which lacked many necessary establishing factors) and did so without losing any of Lewis' charm or intent.Overall, it is a Good Yarn that is worth seeing.

title: Nice adaptation of classic children's book.
content: I like the film. I really do. The film blends drama, comedy, and adventure, very well, and the character development (especially for Edmund) is nice. I also the fight and adventure sequences. Because, yes, it's intense, but I like how they didn't add any blood or gore to keep this film clean, (it IS an adaptation of a children's book after all, so you gotta keep it at the PG rating!) and I like how the film focuses more on the adventure and journey, instead of the violence, like a lot of other adventure films. The acting is great, (especially since children are in this movie) and the cast is amazing. The CGI has also held up very well, and the story is nice, entertaining, well-developed, and lacks dragging, especially for its 143-minute runtime. Overall, this film is a nice, adventure story fit for the whole family, and a good movie to start with if you're looking to get into the action/adventure/fantasy genres.

title: Comparisons comparisons
content: The problem with this movie is that it ends up like little bits of pieces of scenes gathered from various similarly-themed movies. This movie ruined the beauty of C.S. Lewis delicately written imagery by resorting to a badly written book-to-movie script and "seen that, what else is new?" special effects.So basically, that is what really disappointed me when watching the film. It's amazing that FINALLY they bought the book to life... And yet only to watch it go down the toilet drain. Aslan (Liam Neeson) was a great asset to the film, but somehow along the middle it seemed like I was watching a Sesame Street movie.The movie is a mess, it failed to capture the real series. What a disappointed. Watch it if you're a fan of the book but be prepared for the havoc that awaits.1/10

title: Amazing job!
content: I think that the entire story was very creative and imaginative. I loved it all! The actors did a fantastic job on playing their roles as they also did in the following movies. I do wish that they would have made more movies though, perhaps a series with younger characters to fill in the roles of the four children since they are much older now. I've seen all three movies about a dozen times and I would definitely give them a ten out of ten for excellent work and and amazing job on the scenery! I know that these movies were over 5 years ago and I'm just now writing this review, but to those who haven't seen it yet should definitely watch it especially if you're into fantasy, family, and adventure movies!

title: Good Movie. (period/full stop) Not Harry Potter. (period/full stop) No comparisons, please.
content: I beg to differ with Ms. Catherine Jones but this is not a "better movie than Harry Potter" - it is a DIFFERENT movie than Harry Potter. (It's also different than LOTR but there are some similarities.) Obviously, as the 6th or 7th sequel to Narnia comes out the lines will be less firmly drawn but this is simply a different movie about a different book. All three (HP, Narnia, and LOTR) are adaptations of VERY popular book series and, as such, must remain as faithful as possible to the original story to retain fans of the books. But they are distinctly different movies (books) which happen to touch on overlapping themes at times.I have read all of the HP books at least once and the same for LOTR. This is not true about Narnia. However, I have read other C.S. Lewis and, perhaps most importantly, a primordial version of Narnia (not called that but many of the ideas came from there) which Clive wrote with his brother when he was 8 or 9 years old. What IS similar about the three authors, and hence the three movies to some extent, is the ability to build a fantasy world peopled with very real characters who exhibit some very real human traits and situations (in spite of the fact of their fantastic or non-human form).I would not/did not/could not judge this movie in comparison to HP or LOTR because I would have to find it lacking. I would recommend judging it on it's own merits. It is a good move. The series may some day become a great series. But Peter Jackson's LOTR was a feat like none other and stands on it's own. The same is true of the HP series but in a different vein - this is a collection of film adaptations made by a number of different directors yet hearkens to and keeps us connected to the series of books which is still evolving within our lifetime - there is a connectedness between the evolution of the books, the characters, and the films that has it's own appeal - not unlike the serializations of Charles Dickens or Arthur Conan Doyle. But enough of those other series - I said that I dost not compare this movie to they.This first of the Narnia stories was a good movie. By comparison to all lesser movies (common Hollywood drek) it may even be a very, very good movie. But comparing it to HP or LOTR can only reduce it's appeal.The CG was a little less perfect than it could have been. The child actors were outstanding and the adults did not get in the way. (I do think that I will go back and watch some of Ms. Swindon's earlier films such as "Female Perversions" ...)I do recommend it and, especially for the holidays, it is an excellent family movie.

title: Yawn
content: Yeah i just came out of the theater after watching this one and i had to get on here to warn people. Unless you're 10 years old or younger, avoid this movie and save your money. This movie can be best described as a made for TV movie with a bigger budget. Or perhaps it could be seen as a watered down kid's version of Lord of the Rings.The first 3/4 of the movie was a total yawn. Character development is non existent as we are not given any insight about the personalities of the children at all, all we know is that they're children running away from the Nazis. Furthermore, what we do realize about these children are that they are quite the little runts. With exception to the the youngest child, Lucy, the rest are a bunch of malcontent, annoying, complaining, unworthy rodents. Edmond in particular is an obvious pain and i would not be misty eyed at all to see this little brat's existence come to thankful end. The older sister is annoying as well and there are several times during the movie where she was so annoying that you wished you could reach into the movie screen to ring her neck. I was not made to feel any sympathy for these two. The oldest boy, Peter was a bit easier to tolerate however still not worth a care. How could the viewer enjoy this movie if they didn't care for the main character's well beings? A very good question...The story is seriously flawed and also share painful parallels to the triumphant Lord of the Rings movies. For example the death of their leader, who later is resurrected by questionable, and head scratching means. The big battle that seemed to be lost, suddenly saved by a last minute addition of troops. A character that does not wish to take their role as leader but afterwards taking up his sword and marching into battle... Please give me some credit... please give viewers credit... we are not morons, don't treat us like we are.The inhabitants in Narnia also do no make much sense as they do not seem to be able to follow footprints. The White Witch (aka female Saruman) is all powerful, able to freeze anyone with a motion of her staff however fails to be able to dispose of a child who just picked up a sword 2 days ago for the first time. She forgets about all her powers and tries to swat him with swords. Which brings me to another point... how could children who were given weapons by Santa Claus and have had not previous training be able to battle in a war, be better able to lead an army into battle better then any soldier already in the army? Overall this movie was a real disappointment and falls short on many many levels.4 out of 10

title: Very Good Adaptation You'll Enjoy!
content: You will enjoy this movie. Ik this review is coming in late but this movie still holds up pretty well & is worth your time. It won't disappoint both fans of the book & newcomers! 8/10 (Great)

title: The Storyline, The Film, And The Series
content: I am a writer, and these type of series help me and other writers create new story ideas. I truly enjoyed watching this film and storyline instalment. I am sure that other viewers and fans of this series enjoyed it as well. It is a great film that helped bring this series to life. Watching these types of series makes me want to be a part of it.This fil and storyline instalment reveals to viewers and fans what they can learn and use in real life. All the skills and all the heroism that are displayed throughout the film and storyline series can be used by everyone. This is a great film and storyline instalment for everyone. After watching this film and storyline series has given me new story ideas to create.

title: "...Narnia..." Is a Moving Must-See!
content: Fans of "The Chronicles of Narnia" will not be disappointed by this magical adaptation of "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe."When four children enter a magical land full of fantastic creatures--and evil villains--there is sure to be adventure. And adventure there is! "...Narnia..." is packed full of all the best elements of comedy, drama, action, and (of course) fantasy.The costuming is stunning, the scenery is lush, the acting is genuine, the soundtrack is moving, and the story is...well...it's Lewis' best!Anyone interested in remembering how it feels to believe in something will find in this film a meaningful and moving testimony to the power of hope, family, and faith. Bring your imagination and your sense of wonder--and prepare to enter the wardrobe!

title: One of my favourite movies of all time from one of my favourite books of all time
content: I will start off by saying that, while this is a very good movie, I do think that the next two are unfairly criticized for not following the source material as this one did. Now, I haven't seen "Dawn Treader" yet, but I should remind people that "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe," is, in my opinion, the most famous Narnia tale of all the Narnia movies. For this reason, I think that the people behind the scenes had a bit more freedom with the second and third movies, while this one, they had to have it really close to the book in order for it to work the way it did. Don't get me wrong; it is good to follow the books. I'm just saying that "Prince Caspian" and "Dawn Treader" are not as famous as TLTWATW.Now, onto this movie.I'm really surprised that this only got a 6.9. This deserves a way higher rating. I won't go into too much details about the story, but for those who don't know, it's basically about 4 children who end up stumbling into a magical land via wardrobe, and find out about a prophecy that includes them in a huge way.I can't emphasize how much I love this movie. I'm 18 years old, and as a Christian person, I instantly fell in love with this back when it came out in theatres. I wasn't worried about whether or not it would follow the book, and I'm glad I wasn't worried. This film delivers.You could say that the special effects are amazing, but what really steals the show are the performances. Let's start out with the stars of the film: the four Pevensies. William Mosely definitely is the weakest, and is really the only reason why I gave it a 9 out of 10, but he is good. Anna Popplewell has that motherly look that you feel when she is on screen, which makes her perfect for Susan. Skandar Keynes is great as the mean little brat known as Edmund, who learns a "little" lesson as the film goes on. But, Georgie Henley is the star that shines the most. It is through her character that we see Narnia first, and when she's on screen, she gives the child-like energy to her performance that is needed for the character of Lucy.Now, it's not all new faces here. The first movie star that we see is James McAvoy as the faun Tumnus, and he gives off a performance that will make children love Mr. Tumnus just as much as he seems to love them (as seen in his interaction with Lucy). Tilda Swinton gets the most screen time out of the heavyweights here, and she is chilling (no pun intended) in her performance as the White Witch. Fans of the Shrek series will recognize Rupert Everett's (aka Prince Charming) voice as the fox who appears throughout the movie. But, the most recognizable actor here is the voice of Liam Neeson as Aslan. I could listen to that man read a telephone book with that voice. He is among Morgan Freeman and James Earl Jones as to having a soothing voice, and he proves it with his performance of Aslan.Overall, this is a film that should not be missed; it will please you whether you are old or young. The special effects are completely first class, the story is gripping and stays true to the book, and the actors all do their jobs well. A 9/10 for me.

title: Best movie I have ever seen
content: I so love this move! and what a masterpiece it is. The wonderful story of Narnia from the books are retold in a way the the books comes alive. I was very satisfied when the movie was done, and that is not often I am that, after watching a movie based on a book. Good job on this one. I so hope they would keep them going. They have the best message for all to learn, plus all that hidden symbolic makes it all the more fun! Definitely a classic

title: Missing the magic
content: I was rather underwhelmed by my experience of seeing Narnia for a few reasons. Some of the main problems arise from miscasting of the characters:Mr Tumnus: he somehow manages to come across looking like some guy you would meet at a fancy-dress party, or in a bar, albeit in an excessively elaborate costume.Jadis: this character is the most important of the movie and should have been played by a stunningly beautiful actress with a much more powerful screen presence, both in terms of her compelling and admirable (yes) intellect, and her sheer size. She is described in 'The Magician's Nephew' as one of the most beautiful women in the entire world. Tilda Swinton simply has no appeal, and comes across rather meek and albino/alien-esquire. As a result, it is very difficult to conceive the magnetic attraction that Edmund was supposed to have had to the White Witch. Andrew Adamson has said that he wanted to avoid the usual cliché of the "evil stepmother and the cackling witch" that has been seen too many times over the years. He said he wanted to "create a more sophisticated type of evil". While the usual stereotype has been avoided (which is good), its replacement fails to arouse much emotion at all. She could point her wand at me any day and I wouldn't bat an eyelid.The children: Peter's actor seems the least likable. His strong leadership from the book comes across as joyless sanctimoniousness and is off-putting. Susan seems to suffer the worst from the CGI, especially scenes involving wind which doesn't seem to move hair very much. The actress playing Lucy tries desperately to be cute and show wonderment at the unbelievable world around her. Any scenes involving extreme emotion (for example, crying) were the most disappointing. Edmund was actually pretty good.The beavers, and Aslan: The voices, provided by celebrities, did not blend into their scenes. They were simply too loud and too clear. The beavers were the best part of the movie and their lines were met with approving murmurs from the audience around me. Liam Neeson's Irish accent, while slightly modified, seemed odd.Regarding the rest of the movie, I just have a few remarks: The most crucial part of the plot from the book that is left out is the fact that the Turkish Delight given to Edmund is in fact enchanted! The book says "anyone who had once tasted it would want more and more of it, and would even, if they were allowed, go on eating it till they had killed themselves." There are many instances in the movie where either critical information required for the story (such as above), or descriptive narrative, is left out, and the movie loses a huge amount of texture as a result. My solution would have been to include a narrator, making sure that they did not speak in a patronizingly slow manner. Father Christmas is depicted in the movie without his usual, hackneyed red outfit. I considered this to be rather refreshing. However, what Susan says a few scenes later doesn't really fit in as a result - "just because some fellow in a red coat gives you a sword doesn't make you a hero". I noticed that while leopards are featured in the book, the rosetted felines starring in the movie appeared to have cheetah heads, with prominent black 'tear' marks that leopards do not have. The bodies were clearly those of leopards. CS Lewis wrote in a letter: "Anthropomorphic animals, when taken out of narrative into actual visibility, always turn into buffoonery or nightmare -- at least with photography." This unfortunately rang true. I found myself many times thinking how clever the WETA graphics team was, and other times thinking that more work should have been put into the project. My objection to this is that I really don't think I should have been thinking about the WETA team at all.

title: Beautiful adaptation
content: Having grown up reading and adoring the Chronicles of Narnia series, I was understandably nervous to see a film adaptation of such a deeply meaningful book in my life.I remember coming out of the theatre beaming with joy over the respect paid to the source material as well as the powerful insights given by actors to details I'd never considered previously.The music, scenery, and effects are all beautifully done; this movie is a treat both to watch and to listen to.The timeless story leaves you thinking about its depth and symbolism long after you've finished watching it, and it will forever be a favorite of mine, just as the book has been.

title: Best kids fantasy movie !!
content: This is my 2nd favourite movie after Titanic & I love it......The Chronicles of narnia 1 is the best part in Disney.This is splendid for kids just waiting for part 4 to release by Netflix.

title: Dude, Watch This!!!
content: In the movie adaptation of C. S. Lewis' The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe, four siblings are sent to an old country estate to escape the World War Two London bombings. One rainy afternoon, during a game of hide and seek, the youngest child, Lucy, discovers a wardrobe in the spare room and uses it as a hiding place. While hiding in the wardrobe, Lucy stumbles upon a magical land called Narnia, where she meets a Faun called Tumnus. When the false ruler of Narnia, the White Witch, finds out about Tumnus' meeting with Lucy, she takes him prisoner in her castle. Lucy returns to Narnia with her sister and two brothers and they find themselves racing against time to save Mr. Tumnus and free Narnia from the tyranny of the White Witch.Having read the book and watched the movie, I can say that the movie definitely elaborated more on the battle scenes, which was fantastic because they were somewhat hard to follow and grasp in the book. I also liked that the rivalry between Peter and Edmund was played up a little more in the movie than it was in the book. It helped you get into Edmund's head and really understand why he felt so unappreciated. I think this movie really stuck to the main plot of the book, and, even though it missed a few parts that helped the audience understand the White Witch and some of her motives, I definitely recommend that people read this book and watch the movie.

title: Horror
content: First time i saw the preview i had the opinion of seeing something like Lord of the Rings, but now i know this thoughts were a terrible mistake. Rarely i've seen such a pushed film that disappointed me so heavy. Why ?Because of the schematic characters and their bad play. As Lion i would kill the little girl instead of the witch.Logical errors that can't be tolerated. (children who can fight after some training)cheap tricks or they seems to be.The whole story bored my wife and me, both of us wished that the film has to end as fast as possible.Another example of a pushed film with nothing inside.

title: My Review
content: I personally think the director did a splendid job turning the novel into a film. There was a lot of action, which I normally don't enjoy but overall it was still a great movie. The children did amazing at the acting, it was very impressive. The actress playing the white witch did great! Her words were ice cold and when she yelled at Edmund for not being able to bring his family there, it shocked me. Not to mention, the props were stunning! The winter feels and background, the ice castle, everything about it was immaculate. This definitely isn't my favorite but it was very enjoyable.

title: A real Turkish and worldwide delight.
content: I've been reading the book to my school kids ( third fourth and fifth graders) for 30 years and they have all loved the book. One of my kids told his parents about the book and his dad brought back some Turkish delight for us when he went to England. I enjoy the BBC version of the movie because it is so faithful to the book. I wasn't sure I would like this movie version because I knew it added and subtracted from the book. It was so well done and brought the characters so vividly to life that I really enjoyed it anyway. The message of the book stayed intact and that was what really mattered. The only thing that disappointed me a bit was the voice of Aslan. I expected a voice like James Earl Jones - very deep and commanding. I wish they would make an IMAX version.

title: Surprised how much I liked this
content: I originally saw this in the cinema and I felt a bit let down by it. However I watched it again recently on DVD after having seen (and loved) The Dawn Treader. Watching on DVD at home I really loved it! The things that i disliked about the cinema release seemed to have changed... possibly they fixed a few things for home release? The battle scene seemed much longer and not as tame this time (a good thing!) and Aslan seemed bigger than I recall from the cinema. Few movies ever do the books justice, and C.S. Lewis's writing could never be matched, but this movie does do a very good job in bringing it to life. A great film that's quite moving and beautiful at times.

title: Shocking - an old book actually made into a movie
content: I have to say that I hate most new movies. They rip off the title of an old book, throw the rest of the book away and then make some politically-correct garbage claiming it to be the same story that has little if anything to do with what the book said. Here, a Hollywood director actually made a movie that IS the old book. He didn't even remove the Christian parallels that the original writer intended nor did he change the main characters to be something more politically-correct - I am still trying to get over the shock of seeing a novel properly made into a movie. A very good movie well done. I will be looking forward to the rest of the series.

title: The way to Narnia becomes simple
content: My husband and I have loved C.S. Lewis' Narnia stories since we were children. Shortly after we became engaged, he took me to Wheaton College so that I could see the Wardrobe. I had to suppress my joy, but when when I got to open it, the path to Narnia was blocked.After more years than I care to admit, I finally managed to find my way to that a place more comforting than Oz or Wonderland by watching this film. I screamed at Edmund when he placed his trust in the evil Snow Queen because she made him Turkish Delight (something I've never liked, but I tolerate those who do). I was proud of Peter, Susan and Lucy as they braved things that I would have never been able to do by myself.And, then, there's Aslan. He was the giant symbol of great heart, power and love that lions are often equated with. His joy in life and the deep magic which protects everyone alive lies in every movement and that beautiful voice (Liam Neeeson). I'd seen many of the other mythic creatures before with Harry Potter, but here, even these wanting no contact with humans all became heroes fighting for what they believed in, including four children from another place and time.Lewis'series reflects the horror that England went through during World War II and the trouble it endured afterward. It's also true that they contain more than the usual amount of Christian symbolism something that some people of other religions might not care for. No matter that, because the beauty and love the movie creates can be felt by any person of every background. It is one of those things that can unify people from all over the world.When I am full of doubt that the Universe will turn out right, I pull out my copy, watch it, and my doubt starts to go away. You might like to do that, too.If you would like to read more books written by this Oxford Don, you might like _The Screwtape Letters_ and _A Grief Observed_ too.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The music was good!
content: I have no idea what made this movie as big as it is today!? The director had every hand out to him. The story was there already, and these kinds of movies are a big hit right now. But how in the world could he make a movie like that, and why was it shown in cinemas? It would been perfect to show this movie at the HALLMARK CHANNEL over the Christmas, I've would have turned on the Television and not expected a well done movie, but a movie filled with computer animated effects that didn't really look real, but fun! Instead I had to dress up, go out and sit beside a stranger, staring angry at the screen trying and wanting to join the stranger playing with his popcorn! In one scene, where the little girl Lucy, (Georgie Henley) saw here friend turned into stone, she just stood there smiling, but then start's sounding like she's crying and I got confused! We also had these "Peter Jackson, over the hill, camera flying move" but we had it to many times, four times if I remember it right! They should had hired a good makeup artist instead of a bed costume designer! But the music was fantastic; you could hear that the director knew that the music was the only good thing as he tuned it up a lot! IF you haven't seen this movie, then don't! MuggZ

title: Deep Magic!
content: While the dark recesses of many wardrobes are a mystery containing untold treasures and/or horrors, there is a particular wardrobe in a spare room that leads to the magical land of Narnia. A land where the White Witch (evil) has reigned for 100 years, but Aslan the Lion (good) is on the move. This is such a vast and beautiful world that an epic clash between good and evil is inevitable.Set during World War II, the four Pevensie children are sent away from blitz-bombed London to the safety of Professor Kirke's country mansion. Peter and Susan are the elder children and stoically sensible and responsible. The youngest child, Lucy, is sunny and engaging. It is Edmund, desperately missing his father and smarting against the assumed authority of his older siblings, who has some hard lessons to learn about temptation and treachery.Isolated and bored in the sprawling house, the children resort to playing hide and seek. Lucy hides in a wardrobe and stumbles into Narnia, a land frozen in the grip of winter and the evil Witch. This seemingly random event begins the fulfillment of a prophecy of biblical proportions. And the biblical themes that run through these Chronicles are undeniable.The essence of Narnia is Deep Magic. Mythical creatures such as unicorns and griffins, mermaids and centaurs and even Santa Claus mingle with more modest birds, beavers, badgers and wolves. All these animals can talk and even the trees are listening. So who can be trusted? Definitely not the White Witch, with her guilty gifts of Turkish Delight. She is the epitome of evil, breathtakingly icy and chillingly ruthless. As for her followers, fortunately it does seem to be true that evil disfigures and deforms as they are the foulest collection of genetic mishaps we have ever seen.On the other hand, Aslan the Lion is molten gold goodness, with a lion's courage and a true heart. His voice resonates with warmth and it can only be summer in his presence. His followers are a host of the most dazzling beings in Narnia, as well as a myriad of sharp-witted forest animals.The Chronicles of Narnia incorporate CGI at its most seamless. Though for all the awesome scale, its beauty is in the details. Only four of the heroes are human and it is set in a vast, magical land, but this fantasy is warmly familiar. Following his first meeting with Lucy, Mr Tumnus the Faun says that she "made me feel warmer than I've felt in 100 years". This is how we felt about our first trip to Narnia and we can't wait to return.

title: Beatiful, magical and mystical.
content: Having stumbled across this movie relatively later in its life, its undiluted magic still enraptured me as much as it would have done in 2005. The young cast was impressive alongside convincing talking creatures, namely Aslan and the beavers, with a truly mystical backdrop of Narnia, capturing the magic of the scene more effectively than many other titles since, despite improved special effects. The slightly darker nature of this film paired with a wondrous childhood tone, made it a truly consuming two and a half hours. The ending was particularly effective, mirroring the audience's loss of the mysticism of Narnia as they are brought back into the present whilst consoled by the hope of returning to this land. Having said this, most of the humour sprinkled in this title fell flat, seemingly conflicting with the vision of a slightly darker Narnia than conveyed in the books. The strained relationship between Peter and Edmund at times felt too forced, with the only aim to precipitate Edmund's betrayal of his siblings which obviously propelled the narrative forward. Overall, whilst slightly rough around the edges, a beautiful film for all.
